column1: The bird gets it and there is hell to pay in Samuel Taylor Coleridge's Rime of the Ancient Mariner (1798):
'And I had done an hellish thing,
For all averred, I had killed the bird
Ah wretch! said they, the bird to slay,
Punished by his fellow sailors for killing the albatross, the mariner is forced to wear the dead bird round his neck as penance for his evil deed.

A beautiful poem by one of the cofounders of the Romantic Movement (along with William Wordsworth) Samuel Taylor Coleridge's The Rime of the Ancient Mariner has inspired many other writers as well as artists such as Gustave Dore.
